No, because I'm pledged to that, and yes, some taxes have gone up.

I want to give every American a $5,000 refundable tax credit.

You've seen, as middle-income people in this country, incomes go down $4,300 a family, even as gasoline prices have gone up $2,000.

It's a $550 billion tax scheme that will cause a big hole in the deficit which will raise interest rates and slow down the economy and cause people to pay more for home mortgages, car payments, credit card payments, college loans, and small business loans.

When we have a country that's doing so badly, that's being ripped off by every single country in the world, it's the kind of thinking that our country needs, because everybody -- Lester, we have a trade deficit with all of the countries that we do business with, of almost $800 billion a year.
One-third of the president's budget is at the president's discretion, or really the Congress, since they appropriate every dime and tell a president how to spend every dime.

First, we have to build an economy that works for everyone, not just those at the top.
We've got a great economic package which I hope we will discuss later.

And if we don't, we will be spending our children's money.
And remember the Federal deficit has come down $70 billion in one year, in 1987.
That's pennies on the dollar compared to renewing the cold war.

I believe that inflation today is caused by government simply spending more than government takes in, at the same time that government has imposed upon business and industry, from the shopkeeper on the corner to the biggest industrial plant in America, countless harassing regulations and punitive taxes that have reduced productivity at the same time they have increased the cost of production.

Mr. Stone, I have submitted an economic plan that I have worked out in concert with a number of fine economists in this country, all of whom approve it, and believe that over a five year projection, this plan can permit the extra spending for needed refurbishing of our defensive posture, that it can provide for a balanced budget by 1983 if not earlier, and that we can afford - along with the cuts that I have proposed in Government.
We've allocated $7 billion over the next months for reconstruction efforts.
Yes, we have an increase in the defense budget.
But I know this, we have serious financial problems in this country.
So I don't think we can judge on, the stock market has been strong.
You were trying to defend your cut which was not a cut either, Reduction in the growth of spending.

But on his very optimistic figures about his tax cut producing a balanced budget by 1983, and the fact that he is using, he says, the figures of the Senate Budget Committee, that Senate Budget Committee Report does not accommodate all of the Reagan defense plans.

We have made good progress, and there is no doubt in my mind that the commitment to unemployment compensation, the minimum wage, welfare, national health insurance, those kinds of commitments that have typified the Democratic party since ancient history in this country's political life are a very important element of the future.
We're giving them lots of money, lots of everything.
Im- most importantly, consumer confidence as surveyed by the reputable organization at the University of Michigan is at the highest since 1972.

Today it is up a plus 4 percent.

And we're bringing GDP from, really, 1 percent, which is what it is now, and if she got in, it will be less than zero.

They produce the most jobs.

It means that there will be increased employment.
And you could never quite get the job done.

Creating millions of good-paying jobs.

We need to make education the number one priority in our country and treat teachers like the professionals that they are.

I want to make sure the education system fulfills its hope and promise.

That wasn't true in his time, that's why my policy starts with a very robust policy to get all that energy in North America -- become energy secure.
And foreign companies are now coming in buying our -- buying so many of our different plants and then re-jiggering the plant so that they can take care of their oil.
But what I've also said is we can't just produce traditional source of energy.
And we're not going to be able to deal with the climate crisis if our only solution is to use more fossil fuels that create global warming.
I have never said I oppose fracking.
As a matter of fact, oil production is down 14 percent this year on federal land, and gas production was down 9 percent.
And all these things have contributed to us lowering our oil imports to the lowest levels in 16 years.
And I'll bring that pipeline in from Canada.
Energy -- well, first -- second of all, energy independence.

This commitment has been opening up a very bright vista for our nation in the future, because with the windfall profits tax as a base, we now have an opportunity to use American technology and American ability and American natural resources to expand rapidly the production of synthetic fuels, yes; to expand rapidly the production of solar energy, yes; and also to produce the traditional kinds of American energy.
That's why I have a plan for energy independence within 10 years.
I believe we can, for all intents and purposes, eliminate our dependence on Middle Eastern oil and Venezuelan oil.
The only way to become less dependent on foreign sources of crude oil is to explore at home.
And to establish a permanent home heating oil reserve here in the northeast.
She negotiated with the oil companies and faced them down, a $40 billion pipeline of natural gas that's going to relieve the energy needs of the United -- of what they call the lower 48.
I expect those new energy sources to be built right here in the United States.
Less dependency upon foreign sources of crude is good for consumers.
And they provide us energy and they provide us innovation and they start companies like Intel and Google.
We have increased oil production to the highest levels in 16 years.

Number one, we do need to expand domestic production and that means, for example, telling the oil companies the 68 million acres that they currently have leased that they're not drilling, use them or lose them.
We're using our steel capacity fifty-five per cent today.

I think the Wall Street Journal uh reported not too long ago they have a hundred and twelve public relations experts working for the Federal Energy Agency to try to justify to the American people its own existence.

We have to have energy independence, so I've put forward a plan to make sure that, in 10 years' time, we have freed ourselves from dependence on Middle Eastern oil by increasing production at home, but most importantly by starting to invest in alternative energy, solar, wind, biodiesel, making sure that we're developing the fuel-efficient cars of the future right here in the United States, in Ohio and Michigan, instead of Japan and South Korea.
But one mistake he's made is fuel efficiency standards at 40 to 45 miles a gallon will throw many auto workers out of work, and you can't have it both ways.
Because our energy is low cost, that are already beginning to come back because of our abundant energy.

And some major uh - uh - manufacturing companies, like Dow Chemical, have through uh - very effective efficiency mechanism cut down the use of energy by uh - as much as 40 percent with the same out-product.

So, shift from oil to coal, emphasize research and development on coal use and also on solar power, strict conservation measures, not yield every time that the special interest groups uh - put pressure on the president like uh this administration has done, and use atomic energy only as a last resort with the strictest possible safety precautions.
And since I first made that proposal 15 months ago, the price of gasoline, which was then $.80, has gone up to about $1.30.

These have been priorities of mine since I got to the Senate, and it is absolutely critical that we develop a high fuel efficient car that's built not in Japan and not in South Korea, but built here in the United States of America.
It had all kinds of breaks for the oil companies, I mean, billions of dollars worth.
Well, had we joined the Kyoto treaty, which I guess he's referring to, it would have cost America a lot of jobs.

But I do not believe that conservation alone is the answer to the present energy problem, because all you're doing then is staving off, by a short time, the day when you would come to the end of the energy supply.
Let's take advantage of the energy resources we have, as well as the energy sources for the future.
We'll produce more coal this year than any year in history.
You've got one more energy -- you've got one more question.
I want to develop the coal resources in America.
And we know that, if we drill off-shore and exploit a lot of these reserves, it will help, at temporarily, relieve our energy requirements.
And that has had a damaging effect on a lot of the oil companies, right?

I invited the former prime minister of Russia to my house and took a risk in asking him to get personally involved, along with the head of Finland, to go to Belgrade and to take a set of proposals from the United States that would constitute basically a surrender by Serbia.
Well, the resurgence of Russia is one of the central issues that we're going to have to deal with in the next presidency.
We have to remember that the cold war that Mr. Khrushchev is waging and his colleagues are waging, is waged all over the world and it's waged right here in the United States.
We've got to provide moral support to the Poles and Estonia and Latvia and all of the nations that were former Soviet satellites.
National security, economic strength, democracy.
I think the essential strategy of the United States ought not accept any Soviet control over Eastern Europe.
Now, I think the Russians ought to understand that we will support -- we, the United States -- will support the inclusion of Georgia and Ukraine in the natural process, inclusion into NATO.
But as far as other elements of what she was saying, I don't know Putin.
We've got to help Russia succeed in its revolution and all of its republics.

And I really believe that it - it's far better for us and for the Soviet Union, and more importantly for the people around the world, that these two superpowers find an answer for a SALT II agreement before October three, 1977.

And to countries like Georgia and the Ukraine, I think we have to insist that they are free to join NATO if they meet the requirements, and they should have a membership action plan immediately to start bringing them in.
The Soviet Union in 1955 expressed regrets to us over the Bering Sea incident.
And Georgia and Ukraine are both major gateways of energy into Europe.
We have to be tough on the Soviet Union, but I think the American people -- --
I have seen Communism abroad.
We got intimately involved in building NATO and other structures there.
But I think we need to be very careful in the present situation before we invite the Russians to play the lead role in mediating.
Look, there are 50 former national intelligence folks who said that what this, he's accusing me of is a Russian plan.
But in order to stop this arms madness, we've got to push ahead with tough negotiations that are verifiable so that we know the Soviets are agreeing and living up to their agreement.
I have no loans from Russia.
The Soviet Union knows what they want in detente, and they've been getting it.
We have had for many years, understandably, a system of restraints on high technology because the Soviets are behind us.
Let me just quickly say, at the current pace, the president will not secure the loose material in the Soviet Union -- former Soviet Union for 13 years.

And then, as we build up our national security, to restore our margin of safety, we at the same time try to restrain the Soviet build-up, which has been going forward at a rapid pace, and for quite some time.
I don't believe, uh - Mr. Frankel that uh - the Yugoslavians consider themselves dominated by the Soviet Union.
Tell Aleksander Kwasniewski of Poland we're going alone.
And now the Soviet Union seems to be walking down that same path.

Now on the question of disarmament, particularly nuclear disarmament, I must say that I feel that another effort should be made by a new Administration in January of 1961, to renew negotiations with the Soviet Union and see whether it's possible to come to some conclusion which will lessen the chances of contamination of the atmosphere, and also lessen the chances that other powers will begin to possess a nuclear capacity.
I don't believe that the Rumanians consider themselves dominated by the Soviet Union.
I know -- I know about Russia, but I know nothing about the inner workings of Russia.
Part of that, as the Gallup Polls show, is because the Soviet Union made a breakthrough in outer space.
The Soviet Union relationship with Syria is at a very low point.

Well, I think that, given what's happened over the last several weeks and months, our entire Russian approach has to be evaluated, because a resurgent and very aggressive Russia is a threat to the peace and stability of the region.

That's why I'm for Stealth technology, to build a Stealth bomber -- which I've supported for years -- that can penetrate the Soviet air defense system without any hope that they can perceive where it is because their radar system is frustrated.
Ukraine, right now, is in the sights of Vladimir Putin, those that want to reassemble the old Soviet Union.
I've stood up to Russia.

Shortly after I became president in uh - December of 1974, I met with uh - General Secretary Brezhnev in Vladivostok and we agreed to a mutual cap on the ballistic missile launchers at a ceiling of twenty-four hundred - which means that the Soviet Union, if that becomes a permanent agreement, will have to make a reduction in their launchers that they now have or plan to have.
And they installed a Marxist-Leninist totalitarian government.
She has no idea whether it's Russia, China, or anybody else.
And the reason I'm worried is because there's a vicious enemy that has an ideology of hate.
Mosul is on the border of Syria.
You take a look at Mosul.
There are a lot of very important planning going on, and some of it is to signal to the Sunnis in the area, as well as Kurdish Peshmerga fighters, that we all need to be in this.
And by the way, they noticed that you skipped Israel.
It's the route for them to arm Hezbollah in Lebanon, which threatens, of course, our ally, Israel.
And we can see that in both Lebanon and in Central America.
Look at that horrible -- these are radical Islamic terrorists.
And so seeing Syria remove Assad is a very high priority for us.
What's happening in the Middle East, there are developments around the world that are of real concern.

And I know there's a lot of concern about that in some circles, but I think they should have the equipment they need so that Kurdish and Arab fighters on the ground are the principal way that we take Raqqa after pushing ISIS out of Iraq.
That is a red line for us, because not only is Israel's security at stake, but our security is at stake if that unravels.
And they're showing up in Iraq for the same reason.
Take a look at the Middle East.
Barbara, one of the blights on this world is the threat and the activities of terrorists.
And there's going to be an Arab summit, of the neighborhood countries.
You've got every rich Middle Eastern country over there trying to buy nuclear weapons.
Now we cannot allow a second Holocaust.
Then we went in with the multinational force to help remove, and did remove, more than 13,000 of those terrorists from Lebanon.
Osama bin Laden and General Petraeus have one thing in common that I know of, they both said that Iraq is the central battleground.

But we did so in a careful, thoughtful way, making certain that we knew who we were dealing with, that those forces of moderation on the ground were ones that we could work with, and we have to take the same kind of steady, thoughtful leadership when it comes to Syria.
Libya understood that America and others will enforce doctrine and that the world is better for it.
But I think it's important to step back and think about what happened in Libya.
And I will tell you, I will take care of ISIS.
We ought to deal with each of these countries separately.
Secretary Clinton is talking about taking out ISIS.
The Muslim ban is something that in some form has morphed into a extreme vetting from certain areas of the world.
And what we've done during the Bush administration, the Kurds were at the State Department, negotiating, trying to work their differences out.
One is the Middle East, and that is of interest to the whole Western World and the industrialized nations, because of the great supply of energy upon which so many depend there.
